commander.name: Lieutenant-General Neil Methuen Ritchie
commander.previous_service: Chief of Staff to General Auchinleck; Chief of Staff to General Alan Brooke (BEF France); Military Cross 1918

chief_of_staff.name: Brigadier John Francis Martin Whiteley
chief_of_staff.note: Assumed position on 28 March 1942; prior to this date position vacant or unknown

deputy_chief_of_staff.name: Brigadier Eric Edward Dorman-Smith
deputy_chief_of_staff.note: Also Director of Military Operations Cairo; acting deputy chief from April 1942

command.headquarters_location: Western Desert, Egypt (mobile headquarters near Gazala Line)

subordinate_units.commander: Lieutenant-General Reade Godwin-Austen (until Feb 1942), then Lieutenant-General William Gott

tactical_doctrine.role: Field Army headquarters responsible for conducting mobile operations in North African desert. Commanded all British and Commonwealth ground forces in Libya/Egypt theatre during offensive and defensive operations against Axis forces.
special_capabilities: Mobile headquarters capable of rapid displacement
Integrated signals network coordinating multiple corps
Intelligence section with signals intercept capability
Direct liaison with RAF Desert Air Force
tactical_innovations: Development of 'Box' defensive system at Gazala
Integration of armoured and infantry formations across corps boundaries
known_issues: Coordination challenges between infantry (XIII Corps) and armour (XXX Corps)
Extended supply lines from Egyptian ports
Inexperience of army commander in independent field command
Tendency for forward headquarters to lose contact with rapidly moving armoured formations
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Headquarters operated from mobile command caravans allowing rapid displacement. Water consumption critical planning factor. All vehicles equipped with desert navigation equipment and sand channels.

special_rules: Mobile HQ: Can relocate up to 50km per day without penalty
Desert Rats: +1 to desert terrain movement for all subordinate units
Extended Supply Lines: -1 to supply rolls when >200km from Tobruk/Egypt
Corps Coordination: One extra command activation per turn if both corps in radio range

G1_personnel.responsibilities: Personnel management, replacements, leave, discipline, medical coordination

G2_intelligence.responsibilities: Enemy intelligence, signals intercept coordination, aerial reconnaissance analysis, prisoner interrogation coordination
special_units: Liaison with Middle East Intelligence Centre (MEIC)

G3_operations.responsibilities: Operations planning, training coordination, tactical doctrine development, combat orders
G3_operations.note: Largest staff section due to multi-corps coordination requirements

G4_logistics.responsibilities: Supply coordination, transport allocation, fuel/ammunition distribution, maintenance policy

signals.responsibilities: Radio networks, cipher, dispatch riders, telephone lines
signals.equipment: Wireless Set No. 9, No. 11, portable cipher equipment

liaison_officers.responsibilities: Corps liaison, RAF liaison, Allied forces coordination (South African, New Zealand, Indian, Australian units)

headquarters_defense.responsibilities: Perimeter security, convoy escort, traffic control
headquarters_defense.weapons: Bren guns, Boys anti-tank rifles, personal weapons

medical.responsibilities: Medical planning, casualty evacuation coordination, field hygiene

provost.responsibilities: Military police, traffic control, prisoner handling

chaplains.responsibilities: Religious services for multiple denominations (Church of England, Catholic, Presbyterian, Jewish)

source: historylearning.com - Neil Ritchie biography and command dates

known_gaps: Exact staff officer names beyond commander and chief of staff (G1/G2/G3/G4 section heads)
Precise vehicle numbers (estimated from typical British Army HQ establishment)
Detailed subordinate unit strengths (approximated from historical references to ~100,000 total 8th Army strength)

confidence_notes.subordinate_corps: 85% - XIII and XXX Corps confirmed with commanders
confidence_notes.personnel_numbers: 65% - Estimated from typical Army HQ establishments
confidence_notes.vehicles: 70% - Estimated from standard British HQ transport allocation
confidence_notes.staff_sections: 75% - Based on British Army staff organization doctrine
